awd_titl_txt: Construction of New Parallel Time Integrators
awd_abstract_narration:
For many problems in science and engineering experimental data and observations do not provide a complete picture of a system's behavior and computer simulations have become an indispensable tool for studying its evolution. However, the complexity and scale of many application problems make even computer modeling a challenging task. This is particularly true when a system undergoing complex dynamics is modeled using time dependent partial differential equations. In fact, special mathematical techniques known as time integrators must be developed to ensure that the evolution of the system is reproduced on a computer with a reasonable fidelity and in a reasonable time. It is also important that such time integration algorithms have the ability to take advantage of the parallel computational capabilities offered by both supercomputers and workstations. This project will develop new time integration methods that exploit parallelism and novel mathematical ideas in order to achieve higher accuracy and better efficiency when simulating complex systems that evolve over a wide range of temporal and spatial scales. General methods applicable to problems across science and engineering will be developed as well as special schemes particularly optimized for certain applications.  The project will explore the advantages of the new numerical approaches in the context of real-world problems such as computer design of efficient engines and weather prediction. This project will also contribute to educating and mentoring undergraduate and graduate students.

Employing parallelism effectively in the spatial discretization of partial differential equations has proven to be revolutionary in computational science.  Recent developments in time integration provide an opportunity to extend these gains to the time domain. This project will combine ideas from exponential and polynomial interpolation-based temporal integration to construct new parallel time integrators. Both parallelization across the method (i.e. over each time iteration) and parallelization across time steps (i.e.  simultaneous computation of the solution over multiple time intervals) will be explored. New approaches for fine-tuning the parameters to optimize performance of the new methods will also be investigated.  The behavior of the new methods will be studied in context of real application problems such as modeling reactive flows involved in combustion.  An additional objective of this work is to provide a guide for determining which of the new techniques are best suited for problems with a given structure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the dynamics of a complex system is an integral part of many scientific and engineering problems. Since experimental data and observations can be limited in providing a full picture of the system's behavior, computer simulations play an indispensable role in research. Numerical modeling is particularly important for understanding the behavior of complex systems evolving over a wide spectrum of temporal scales, such as, for instance the chemical and hydrodynamic processes constituting combustion. Simulating dynamics of these so-called stiff large scale systems requires very efficient algorithms that are particularly suited for high performance computing platforms.  This project focused on development of numerical methods that enable efficient simulations of complex large-scale stiff dynamical systems.  In particular, several novel parallel time integrators have been constructed, analyzed, implemented and tested in the course of this work.  Ideas of exponential integration and parallel-in-time methods have been combined to produce algorithms that significantly extend capabilities of current state-of-the-art temporal integrators.  In particular, we have introduced a new exponential Parareal method that provides significant parallel speedup on both hyperbolic and dispersive equations. We have also proposed a new class of implicit-exponential methods that possess the advantages of preconditioned implicit and exponential algorithms.  In addition to theoretical advances in development and analysis of new time integration methods applicable to a wide range of stiff problems, we have constructed, implemented and tested practical algorithms for computational combustion and flagellar locomotion in low Reynolds number flows.  We were able to show that using exponential and linearly implicit methods for simulating beating flagella in a fluid with low Reynolds number, provides an order-of-magnitude  efficiency gains compared to commonly used explicit integrators. We have made advances in computational combustion in two main directions.  First, we were able to develop exponential-type variable time step integrators for chemical kinetics part of combustion models.  Specifically, we have demonstrated the promise of the new exponential algorithms to deliver computational savings when applied to simulating chemistry of combustive processes that involves large number of chemical species.  Additionally, we were able to show that such methods are also promising when hydrodynamic forces are accounted for and evolved with an exponential integrator.  In fact, the numerical approach we proposed to simulate such phenomena as flame front propagation eliminates the necessity for splitting in a time integrator, and thus allows to improve accuracy and efficiency of combustion simulations.  These initial studies not only introduced new numerical approaches for computational combustion but also highlighted promising new directions of research. To summarize, the project yielded both, new numerical methods and approaches for a wide range of large-scale stiff systems of differential equations as well as concrete algorithms for important problems in combustion and low Reynolds number locomotion.
